comment._content: Do you know what these ships were? Were they people coming across the Channel or the Atlantic to visit the Expo?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: hi edwardaggie98 - Just to give you some background information. This is in a drawer alongside photos documenting a steamship leaving for Europe, presumably from New York. In a letter dated July 8, 1900, Goodyear describes his booking on a ship, the Hamburg-America “Pennsylvania” leaving NY on July 14th, landing at Charbourg and then on to Paris. [W.H. Goodyear Collection Dept. of Fine Arts [3.1.007]] This image is part of the Paris Exposition group of slides and may be a visual record of his travel to the exposition. The following citation yields an image and information for the “Pennsylvania” of the Hamburg-America Line, which leads us to believe it may be the ship in the photo. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Pennsylvania_(1896)

comment.author: 69398923@N00
comment._content: Interesting history - thanks for the update!
